Foreword
Aircraft refueling services is provided by different Airfield Refueling
Stations (AFS) of the oil companies. AFS is located primarily at the airside-
landside perimeter. At certain airports these facilities are located outside
airport perimeter. Aviation Turbine Fuel (ATFI is dispensed from specially
designed refuellers, which are driven up to parked aircraft. The supply
chain security of these vehicles and hydrant refueling systems that pump
the fuel right up to the filling outlets on the tarmac through underground
pipelines are extremely \'ulnerable. These facilities are the tempting targets
for the Iorces of disruption.
A wide spectrum of security threats is faced by fuel farms with petty
pilferage at one end and terrorist attack at the other in civil aviation sector.
Therefore, most eflective security arrangements should be available to the
assets of the fuel farm.
Fuel Farms are also responsible for aviation security which inter alia
includes but not Iimited to:

airside or airport SRAs in compliance with national aviation security
regulations and t}Ie ASP;
applying appropriate physical security measures to items stored
and/or passing through their facility into airport SRAS;
contingeflcy planning consistent with their responsibilities under
the aAport contingenry plan;
developing, where appropriate, an iflternal quality control
programme, a]:rd performing quality control functions over activities
within ttreir sphere; and
ensuring that their employees are adequately informed of tlle
security requirements at tlle airport, providing those with direct
security responsibilities with appropriate training, and providing
lheir slaJT with security awareness training.
